awd_titl_txt: Long-Range, mm-Scale Wireless Optical Power Delivery Using Nanophotonic Antennas and Integrated Power Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The need for wireless power delivery has grown in recent decades, driven by exponential (Moore's law) semiconductor scaling, the pervasiveness of portable computing and communications devices, and other applications including biomedical devices, transportation and aerospace. This project will explore delivering power to small (mm-scale) silicon integrated circuits via a free-space optical (near-IR laser) power source. The goal of the project is to study and demonstrate the feasibility of long-range optical power delivery in a silicon platform through an interdisciplinary effort on semiconductor optics/photonics and low power integrated circuit design. This project will focus primarily on the optical receiver technology including the design and fabrication of nanophotonic antennas to concentrate energy into small silicon-based photovoltaic cells that are implemented in a low-cost standard process flow. The circuits portion of the project will explore methods to extract maximum energy from the optical elements and provide a seamless interface between on-chip dielectric energy storage and a low-voltage embedded circuit load. This project will support educational opportunities in the undergraduate and graduate curriculum at Dartmouth, as well as an expansion of ongoing K-12 outreach programs and communication with the general public. An example of this is the Dartmouth-organized 'Design-it, Build-it' summer bootcamp for high school juniors and seniors that attracts students from around the country and encourages students with underrepresented backgrounds to attend through the provision of scholarship support.

This project will explore several promising technical directions related to mm-scale optical power delivery. A first direction is the design and implementation of near-IR (~850 nm) nanophotonic antenna structures, which can concentrate optical power to small photodiodes (PDs) operated in photovoltaic (PV) mode. These have the advantage of concentrating optical energy into very small optically-active structures, which can improve quantum efficiency and reduce active area needed for optoelectronics, thereby decreasing overall size. Second, we will explore integration strategies in SOI or triple-well CMOS where multiple photodiodes can be dynamically reconfigured in parallel and series stacks. This will help alleviate stress on the power circuitry, enable much higher system efficiency, and benefit from recent developments in power management for photovoltaic (PV) systems. Third, we plan to develop a novel power management approach based on high-density switched capacitor (SC) converters that can provide efficient regulation and power-point tracking with a monolithic implementation while interfacing between high-voltage dielectric storage and a low-voltage embedded system load. The proposed SC architecture builds on past work by the PIs in chip-scale power conversion, architectures that can to mitigate systemic energy loss mechanisms in photovoltaic arrays, and new directions in high-order interleaving and bottom plate recycling that can improve efficiency and power-density.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Dartmouth College- Thayer School of Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
A variety of small scale, low power and portable devices require or would benefit from efficient and effective means of wireless power delivery. Such devices and applications include distributed sensor networks, wearable devices, biomedical implants, microrobotics, and a range of other devices. Unfortunately, conventional electromagnetic coupling is subject to severe limitations that impact both power delivery and transmission range. This project explored alternative means of power delivery that use an optical (photonic) wireless power tether. Optical power delivery shows tremendous potential especially for long range power transmission due to lower power reduction in scenarios where the ratio of transmission range relative to device (or antenna) size is large.

In this program we explored methods to integrate optical antennas; i.e. very small photovoltaic cells in standard silicon-on-insulator (SOI) CMOS semiconductor processes. We used conventional diffusion layers available in these processes to characterize and optimize these cells. We developed methods to stack and arrange photovoltaic cells in series and parallel arrays to achieve relatively high voltage output as could be used for a range of conventional electronic applications. We explored means of transmitting energy via an optical tether across a range of wavelengths from white (conventional fiber light) to collimated (near IR laser). We explored optical antennas that leverage photonic structures based on an e-beam lithography nano-grating.

In parallel, a variety of CMOS integrated circuit design activities were conducted to explore complementary energy harvesting and power management functions. A high-voltage buffer-driver circuit was designed and implemented for applications which required high-voltage pulse drives such as micro-electro-mechanical system (MEMS) actuators implemented in both silicon and piezoelectric technologies. The high-voltage buffer was able to leverage a high-voltage on-chip micro-PV array to drive nF-range loads at over 120V while using a total quiescent power of <1uA for four drive channels. A second integrated circuit prototype, leveraging an efficient switched capacitor circuit improved significantly on the first prototype. The second-generation (Gen-2) prototype demonstrated comparable driving voltages of over 100V but with over 10 times lower total power consumption. This allowed the system to drive up to 10 times higher power electrostatic loads at higher frequencies. The second prototype also demonstrated effective mitigation of variation of on-chip PV cells; such variation coming from process technology mismatch and non-uniform profiles of the optical power source.

Overall the program demonstrated a new direction in both wireless power delivery technologies that leverage optical tethers and silicon CMOS integrated circuitry that can be used for a range of interface and drive applications. The program resulted in four peer reviewed journal or conference publications and wider dissemination of associated research concepts to both academic communities and the general public. It helped support training of four graduate student researchers. The program helped facilitate a broader impact in optical and integrated circuit technology and also through outreach activities including ?open house? research nights for interaction with the general public and summer bootcamps for high-school juniors and seniors, exposing them to next generation concepts in engineering.

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2021
Modified by: Jason Stauth
